T h e Nobility, G e n t r y , and t h e Public.in general, are most respectfully acquainted, that

The Grand Performance of Antient and Modern Music, on Friday next^ will
lake place at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane.
The Perfonuers in the Choruses, under the Superintendence of Mr. WATSON, will be numerous, and assisted by the Young Gentlemen of
His Majesty'^ Chapel Royal, St. Paul's Cathedral, and Westminster Abbey.

Doors will be opened at half-past Six. The Performance will commence at Seven o'clock.

KINO JOHN is unavoidably postponed on account of the indisposition of
Mr. Macready.

The New Farce called The DUEL; or, MY TWO NEPHEWS
having been received with shouts of laughter and applause, and announced for repetition without
a dissentient voice, will be repeated Tomorrow, Thursday and Saturday next.
Tomorrow, the Comedy of The SCHOOL for SCANDAL.
On Widm**day, there will be no Performance.
On Thursday, (in consequence . f its very brilliant reception on Saturday night) the Opera of The
MARRIAGE of FIGARO will be repeated ; when the Counte»s Alrnaviva will be.personated
by Miss M. TREE, and Susanna by Miss PATON
The Publick is respectfully informed
that these Young Ladies will continue to act the above-mentioned characters alternately.
After which, the New Farce, and the Pantomime.
On Saturday (in consequence of the great applause with which it was last Tuesday received>
Shaks P eare'» COMEDY of ERRORS—(with Musk-k) will be repeated

Thet^oinetly of Errors is unavoidably postponed on account of the indisposi ion of a principal Performer.

The New Farce called The DUEL; or, MY TWO NEPHEWS
having been received every night with shouts of laughter and applause,
will be repeated on Tuesday and Thursday next.
On Monday will be revived S-hnkspeare's Tragedy of KING JOHN.

MARRIAGE ol FIGARO will be repeated ; when the Gountes*. Aln>aviva will be personated
by Miss PATON, and Susanna by Miss M.TREK

that these Young Ladies will continue to act the above-mentioned characters alternately.

was repeated on Monday evening, and again received from a most brilliant house, universal and
rapturous testimonies of puhhuk approbation. Thursday's performance was announced amidst

that it will be acted three times a week until further notice.

acted for t h e 4th time, last night, w a s again received by an overflowing audience vi ith the strongest
marks of approbation—the interest of the story was deeply felt, and the enthusiasm which the acting
excited on the fall of the curtain, induces the Management to .'ii.nouiH e it for repetition, every night
till further notice—Benefits excepted.

<r The new Opera of CLARI has been unavoidably postponed on account of
the indisposition of Mr. PEARMAN, but will be repeated for the 9th time
on Wednesday next.
C E N T , per C E N T . ;

or,

The

MASQUERADE

T H E A T R E ROYAL,

Covent- Garde?
It is with the utmost respect the Publick are acquainted that the

Whole Interior of this Theatre
having undergone an entire revision—and a most material Improvement, it
is hoped, having been atchieved, in all that can conduce to the gratitication
of the Town in

DECORATION and CONVENIENCE,
COMFORT and HEARING,

The Performances will

Re-commence

ON

Wednesday next, Oet. 1 ,
WITH A

Farce

Plaj

Which uill be duly announced.
IT will not be attempted to point out the VARIOUS and EXTENSIVE ALTERATIONS which have
been in progress through every working hour during the recess.—The Publick are thoroughly acquainted
with the Theatre, and if the Proprietors have succeeded in their Endeavours, will generously appreciate
what they have done, and give them credit for their Efforts.
But perhaps it may be necessary to inform
the frequenters of the PIT, that the Money-Door is now nearer to the Entrance than before, and that a Space
has been appropriated to those Ladies and Gentlemen who may arrive too soon for the Second Price, where
they may remain, undisturbed by intruders, till the proper time for admission.
It is also respectfully announced, that the unremitted attention which has been ln-stowed on the Alterations of the Theatre, before the Curtain, has not been the cause of any relaxation in industry to provide for
the entertain men t of the Publick on the Stage—Performers of the first ability, in every department, have
either been Re-engaged, or newly added to the Company.

Mr. YOUNG is re-engaged.
Mr. SINCLAIR ^lately returned from Italy, after an absence of Six
Years/ will make his Re-appearance.
Mr. COOPER, of Draw-Lane,
Mr, RAYNER, of the Emrlish Opera-House,
and Miss HAMMERSLEY, of the Liverpool Theatre,
Are added to the Establishment.

A very YOUNG LADY, of great Musical Promise, fa Pupil of Sir G.
Smart J will also make her Debut in the course of the Season.
And many other Performers, with much D R A M A T I C S NOVELTY, will
be introduced in succession.
The BOX-OFFICE will be opened under a New Arrangement, by which every facility will be afforded
to the Publick in obtaining Places. Any Communications addressed to the Box-Book-Keeper, (of whom
PR!VATP- BOXES may be had nightly) will be immediately attended to.
DOORS to be opened at HALF past SIX—the Play to begin at SEVEN.
Boxes It

S-cond Price .~s. 6d

Pit :1s. Orl.— ^esond Price 2e.—Gallery 2s.—Second Price I s ,
Ilppei Gallery 1*.—Second Price (id.

IT will not be attempted' to point out the VARIOUS and EXTENSIVE ALTERATIONS -.hirh have
been in progress during the recess.—The Publiclc are thoroughly acquainted with the JTheatre, and if the
Proprietors have succeeded in their Endeavours, will generously appreciate what they have done, and give
them credit for their Efforts.
But perhaps it may be necessary to inform the frequenters of the PIT.tthat
the Money-Door is now nearer to the Entrance than before, and that a Space has been appropriated to those
Ladies and Gentlemen who may arrive too toon for the Second Price, where the) nay remain, undisturbed by
intruders, till the proper time for admission.
It is also respectfully announced, that the unremitted attention which has been bestowed on the Alterations of the Theatre, before the Curtain, has not been the cause of any relaxation in industry to provide for
the entertainment of the Publick on the Stage—Performers of the first ability, in every department, have
•itber been Re-engaged, or newly added to the Company.

Mr. YOUNG is re-engaged.
Mr. SINCLAIR (lately returned from Italy, after an absence of Six
Years) will make his Re-appearance.

and Miss HAMMERSLEY, of the Liverpool Theatre,
Are added to the Establishment.

A very YOUNG LADY, of great Musical Promise, (a Pupil of Sir G.
Smart J will also make her Debut in the course of the Season.
And many other Performers, with much DRAMATICK NOVELTY, wiL
be introduced in succession.

been in progress during the recess.—The Publick are thoroughly acquainted with thejTheatre, and if the
Proprietors have succeeded in their Et.dea.ours, will g.nercusly appreciate what they have done, and give
them credit for their Efforts.
But perhaps it may b . neeeesary to iniorr. the frequenter, of the PIT, that
the Money-Door is now nearer to the Entrance than before, and that a Space has be.a appropriated to those
Ladies and Gentlemen who may arrive too soon for the Second Price, wh.re they may remain, nndisturbed by
intruders, till the proper time for admission.

was reeeived last night, on his return to Covent Garden Theatre, with a. warm and tumultuous a welcome aa ever

is in • forward state of revival at this T h e a t r e , and will shortly b e produced with an attention t o

Costume which has never been equalled on t h e English Stage. Every Character will a p p e a r in t h e
precise habit oT the P e r i o d — t h e whole of the Dresses and Decorations being executed from copies
of indisputable authority, such a s M o n u m e n t s , Seals, illuminated Manuscripts, painted G l a s s , &e.

Mr, SI IS ( L A I R .
THE PI BUCK IS RKSPECTl I I.I.Y INFORMED THAT

LastWednesday Mr. SINCLAIR made his long- promised re-appearance after a six
years absenee in Italy—The
Theatre teas crowded in every part—«nd however
highly expectation had been excited by the fame which he had acquired upon
the Continent,his reception fromWednesday
night's audience (in which a ere assembled the first musical judges ofthe Kingdom) amply confirmed the reputation
which the Italian Con oscenti had preciously conferred upon him—His welcome
exceeded all which the most sanguine expectation had anticipated; moat of his
Songs were encored, and the favourite
Polacca " No more by sorrow, Ike."
repeated T H R I C E by general acclamation.
M i s s P A T O N was also honoured
with several encores—and the whole Opera gave such universal
satisfaction,
that on t/ie dropping of the Curtain, the audience enthusiastically
demanded
its repetition for last night—bitt upon a respectful remonstrance from the
Manager, they were induced to defer its second representation till
Tomorrow,
with a promise that it should be repeated on Tuesday, Thursday, and SatWr^
day in the ensuing week.

TWORROW;r^rhe~MBTOCTi
Wtakmeartf* Trqgedy of KING

JOHN

will b e revived -at this T h e a t r e on M O N D A Y N E X T , and be produced with an attention t o
C o s t u m e which has never been equalled on the English Stage. Every Character will a p p e a r in t h e
precise habit of t h e P e r i o d — t h e whole of the Dresses and Decorations being executed from copies
of indisputable authority, such a s M o n u m e n t s , Seals, illuminated Manuscripts, painted G l a s s , &c.

represei tition of T h e C A B I N E T , the Pit overflowed in ten minutes ofler the
Ihxns were opened—the House was crowded in every part—and the enthusiasm

- ~ ^ 3 A U J E Q U I N and POOR ROBIN,
is every night received by a crowded and delighted audience with shouts of admiration and applause! J r h e beauty of the Scenery— the ingenuity of the Tricks—the rapidity of the Changes—
and the irresistible drollery of the Incidents, were crowned, on the first night of its representation,
with Three distinct Huzra»>—and each night it is repeated it increases in favour.

T H E COMEtuY OV

was repeated last Thursday, for the 3d time, to au overflowing house—but in consequence of previous arrangements it cannot be acted again till Tuesday •week.
— — —

—

T H K NEW r.YNtOM.MK. U l

"

H A R L E Q U I N and POOR R O B I N ,
is every night received bv a crowded and delighted audience with shouts of admiratio-a and applause——The beauty of the Scenery— the ingenuity of the Tricks—the rapidity of the Changes—
and the irresistible drollery of the Incidents, were drowned, on the first night of its representation
with Three distinct Huzza.)—and each night it is repented it increases in favour.

ASTNEW

OPERA

( w h i c h 1ms b e e n l o n g in preparation)
is in r e h e a r s a l , and will s p e e d i l y b e p r o d u c e d .
W i t h Musick c o m p o s e d by Mr. B l S H O P , and .some Selections from R O S S I N I — n e w S c e n e s ,
D r e s s e s , D e c o r a t i o n s , &c.

On Ash-Wednesday,

there will be No Performance.

'I he Pubiick is respectfully informed that
In consequence of Miss PATON having long been permitted to make an Engagement at Bath for

S/arery,

Direction of Mr. BOCHSA.

The SUCCESS

of the .Yew Comedy,

entitled

PRIDE SHALL HAVE A FALL,
has not been equalled by that of any other, produced for many years—the
applause on each ni%ht it has been acted, was loud and unanimous, and the
Curtain fell amid the rapturous cheers of a delighted audience,—Last
night the House filled the moment the Doors were opened, and was crowded
from top to bottom—it trill be repeated on Thursday and Saturday next,
—and three times a week till further notice. Not an Order wdl be admitted
when it is acted.

The SUCCESS

of the .Vetv Comedy,

entitled

PRIDE SH.ILL HAVE A FALL,
Juts not been equalled by that of any other, produced for many years—the
applause on each night it has been acted, was loud and unanimous, and the
Curtain fell amid the rapturous cheers of a delighted audience,—Last
Tuesday the House was crowded—it will be repeated on Saturday and Monday
•—and three times a iveek till further notice. Not an Order will lie admitted.

HANDEL's SACRED ORATORIO,

E MESSIAH,
With the additional Accompaniments by MOZART.

F A R T i.
OVERTURE.

Recit. Mr. BRAHAM—Comfort ye my people.
Air—Every valley shall be exalted.
Chorus—And the glory of the Lord shall be revealed.
Recit. Mr. BELLAMY—Thus saith the Lord of Hosts.
Air—But who may abide the day of his coming?
Chorus—And he shall purify the sons of Levi.
Recit. Miss VENES—Behold! a virgin shall conceive and bear a Son.
Air and Chorus— O thou that tellest good tiding*.
Recit. Mr. BELLAMY—For, behold ! darkness shall cover the earth.
Air—The people that walked in darkness.
Grand Chorus—For unto us a Child is born.
I'ASTOHAU SYMPHONY.

Recit. Mrs. SALMON—There were shepherds abiding in the field. Chorus—Glory to God.
Air, Mrs. SALMON—Rejoice greatly.
Eecit. Miss VENES—Then shall the eyes of the blind be opened.
Air—He shall feed his flock like a shepherd.
Air, Miss STEPHENS—Come unto him, all ye that labour and are heavy-laden.
Chorus—His yoke is easy, and his burden is light.
Between the First and Second Puts.

A Concerto on the Flute, Mr. NICHOLSON.
PART II.
Chorus—Behold the Lamb of God.
Air, Miss M. TREE—He -was despised and rejected of men.
Chorus—Surely he hath borne our griefs.
Chorus—All we, like sheep, have gone astray.
Recifc Mr. BRAHAM—All they that see him laugh him to scorn.
Chorus—He trusted in God that he would deliver him.
Recit. Mr. BRAHAM—fhy .ebukehath broken hi* heart.
Air—Behold and see.
Recit Miss STE PHENft—He was cut off out of the land or Uie living.
Air—But thSu didst not leave his soul ia beH.
Semi-Chorus, (the PRINCIPAL SINGERS)—Lift up your heads, O ye gates
Full Chorus—The Lord of Hosts.
Recit—Mr. PYNE— Unto which of the angels.
Chorus—-Let all the angels of Go 1 worship him.
Air, Mr. BELLAMY—Thou art gone up on high.
Chorus—The Lord gave the word.
Air, Miss GOOD ALL—How beautiful are the feet!
Quartette, Miss GOOD ALL, Mr. HAWES, Mr. P Y N E , and Mr. BELLAMY, and Chorus—Their sound is gone out into all lands.
Air, Mr. BELLAMY-—Why do the nations so furiously rage together?
Chorus—Let us break their bonds asunder.
Recit. Mr. BRAHAM—He that dwelkth in heaven.
Air—Thou shalt break them with a rod of iron.
Grand Chorus—Hallelujah !
Between the Second and Third Part.,

Grand Fantasia, Piano Forte, Mrs. ANDERSON, in which will be introduced the National Air, " Rule Britannia/'
(by particular desire.)
Ries.
PART in.
Air, Miss STEPHENS—I know that my Redeemer liveth.
Semi-Chorus, (the PRINCIPAL SINGFRS)—Since by man came death.
Full Chorus—By man came also the resurrection of th« dd.
Semi-Chorus, (the PRINCIPAL SINGERS)—For as in Adam all die.
Full Chorus—Even so in Christ shall all be made alive.
Recit. (accompanied) Mr. BELL AMY—Behold I tell you a mystery.
Air—The trumpet shall sound.
(Trumpet Obligate, Mr. NORTON.)
BecJt Miss VENES—Then shall be brought to pass.
Duet, Miss VENES and Mr. PYNE—O Death 1 where is thy sting?
Chorus—But thanks be to God.
Air, Miss GOODALL—If God be for us, who can be against us ?
Grand Chorus—Worthy is the Lamb.

of the A Vic Comedy,

HrlYB

entitled

etf

FALL,

has not been equalled by that of any other, produced for many years—the
applause on each niuht it has been acted, was loud and unanimous, and the
Curtain fell amid the rapturous cheers of a delighted audience,—East
night the House filled the moment the Doors were opened, and before the
Piay began was crowded from top to bit torn—It is with some concern the
JManager is obliged to announce, mat owing to previous arrangements it can
only be acted twice before Easter, viz. on Saturday and Tuesday next.
Tomorrow, there will be No Performance.

The New Comedv, in three acts, called

CHARLES the SECOND; or the Merry Monarch
was last night produced at this Theatre—and, if warm and unanimous
applause be a proof of Success, this Comedy was as eminently Successful as
the most sanguine expectation could have anticipated——it will he repeated
To-night and Tomorrow. But, in consequence of previous arrangements, it
can anlu he acted twice next week, viz. Wednesday and Friday—Monday being
dedicated to HENRY IV.—Tuesday to PRIDE—Thursday, to Mr. SINCLAIR'S
Benefit—and Saturday being Whitsun Eve—No Play.
Tomorrow,

a C O M E D Y , in three a c t s , called

CHARLES the SECOND; or, The MERRY MONARCH.

COZENING.

C H A R L E S the S E C O N D ; or the Merry

Monarch

has been acted eight times, and each representation has been honoured by an
increase of approbation—Last Saturday the house was most brilliantly and fashionably attended—the application for Places is equal to that of any Flay of
the season.Ouing to the near approach of the close, the arrangements will only
•permit its repetition three times this week, viz. Wednesday. Friday & Saturday.

has been acted nine times, and each representation has been honoured by an
increase of approbation—Last night the house was most brilliantly and fashionably attended—the application for Places is equal to that of any lHay of
the season.—It will be repeated on Saturday and Tuesday next.

MASQUERADE
To the Ijondon Performers oj all the London Theatres^

Wild have kindly accepted his Invitation—And
a few Select Friends, who are requested to intiin&t*
their intention of appearing- in Character, cr in Domino, by a N o t e addressed to Mi. Fiara.*..

Divertisertienjs, on the Plan adopted in foreign Ccim.ries;
SCENE

MASQUERADE

SCENE.

JVight, biautifully illuminated with coloured Lamps, discovering numerous Masks, in Caves, in Grott-s, B.fCe-itfj. de Jaidin, &c.—Balloons, and various Pyiotechnkk D'n'ifes, will diversify tb£ Scene.

-fritfrs of Germany, i s not of impossible M c V f W e — 1 shall not bpsupposed as according the remotest degree of
.serious faith to such an imagination; yet, in assuming it a., the basis M a uork of fancy, I have not .onsidere.t
nm-elf as merely weaving .t series of supernatural ti rrors. The event on whit h the interest of the story depends is
exempt from the disadvantages of a mere t.ile of spectres Ar enchantment ; it was recommended by the novelty of
he situation which it devclopes; and, however impossible as a physical fact, affords a point of view totheimugi, at ion, fir the delineating of the human passions, more comprehensive and < ommamiing than any which the ordinary relations of existing events can yield."

writers of Germany, ts not nf i.npos.,ible.occurrenre.—I shall not he supposed as according the rem..test degree of
serious faith to .such an imagination; yet, in assuming it as the basis of a work of fancy, I have not considered

the highly popular Romance, of peculiar ai il terrific interest, called

PRESUMPTION:
Or, The F A T J B OF

The .V'tsick comprised l/i/ Mr. \V \TSOS.
" The event on which this fiction is founded lia^ been suppos,-.,. by Dr. DARWIN, and some of the physiological
writers of Germany. ..s not id impassible oirurrmre.—1 shall not he supposed as according the mnwtuit decree of
•eriw. faith to such an imagination ; yet, in assuming it as the basis of a work of fancy, 1 have not considered
myself as merely .caving a series ot supernatural tninrs. The event on which tlie interest of \he story depends is
txen.pt from the di«advaatage« of a men- tale of spt ctres or enchantment ; it was recommended by the novelty of
the situation \vbi.h it 4e#.j«p..s; and, however impossible as a physical fact, affords a point of vi.w to the imagination, tor the ilt-U.e«ti.R.f th«hi>iii:in passions, more comprehensive and commanding than ai.y which lh6,ordi-s
nary relations atf txiatiug r,t,rt« can yield."

" The event on which this fiction is founde'l has been supposed, by Dr. D.oiwi v, and ,-ome of the physio'o^ical
wrr.-ers of Germany, -,s uot of impossible occurrence.—I shall not besupc.>srd as according the remotes, degree of
.'))•- us faith to such an imagination ; yet, in assuming it as; the basis of a work of fanry, i have not considered
liiytelf as merely weaving < series o. supernatural t. iror?. 1 he evrjit on which the intl-rest of (be story depend-, is
exi nipt from the disadvantages of a mere tale of spectres or enchantment ; it was recommended by the novelty of
the situation which it devi-lnpes; and, however impossible as a physical f<iet, affords a point of virw to the itnagiit-u.on, for the deliueating of the human passions, more comprehensive and comuimding than any which the ord nary relations of existing events cao yield."

THEATRE ROYAL,

COVENT-GARDEN.

This present F R I D A Y , December 10, '1824,
Will be performed Shakspfare's Comedy of

As You L i k e It.
